headline: The Whole Story with Anderson Cooper
subHeadline: Donald Trump Criminally Indicted In Georgia; Fulton County District Attorney Also Charged 18 Co-Defendants Along With The Former President. Aired 8-9p ET

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Welcome to The Whole Story. I'm Anderson Cooper. Foreign President Donald Trump has now been criminally indicted in Georgia for allegedly trying to overturn the election in that state in 2020. This is now his fourth indictment. The Fulton County District Attorney also charged 18 co-defendants along with the former president, including former White House Chief of Staff, Mark Meadows; Trump attorneys, Rudy Giuliani, Sidney Powell, John Eastman and others.Trump is accused of being the head of a criminal enterprise and racketeering is one of the 13 charges against him. Tonight, we take a closer look at exactly what Mr. Trump and his allies did in Georgia in the weeks after the election. CNN's Sara Murray lays out details about the investigation to the former president and the most serious charges he's now facing. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Breaking news into CNN this hour prosecutors in Georgia have opened a criminal investigation --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: -- investigation into former President Trump. Why? Because of his January phone call to the Georgia Secretary of State.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: -- focus on the former President's attempts to influence the administration of the 2020 Georgia general election.GEOFF DUNCAN, (R) FORMER GEORGIA LT. GOVERNOR: Donald Trump got beat by Joe Biden, handily. DONALD J. TRUMP, 45TH PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: There's no way we lost your power was a rigged election.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: He went on a warpath like a scolded child to do anything he possibly could overturn that election.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: They defrauded us out of a win in Georgia. And we're not going to forget it.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: I underestimated his willingness to push the envelope as far as he did, to just bold faced lie again and again and again.

utterances.speaker: SARA MURRAY, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Three months after the election, the District Attorney in Fulton County, Georgia, Fani Willis officially opened an investigation into former President Donald Trump's efforts to overturn the state's presidential election results.

utterances.speaker: FANI WILLIS, DISTRICT ATTORNEY, FULTON COUNTY
utterances.sentences: This is a criminal investigation. We're not here playing a game. I plan to use a power of the law because I sit here in this jurisdiction, it's my responsibility.TAMAR HALLERMAN, SENIOR REPORTER, ATLANTA JOURNAL-CONSTITUTION: Fani Willis is known as a prosecutors prosecutor. She's known as a tough cookie, who's a real preparer. She likes to say I don't like to try things skinny. I don't like to be in a courtroom unprepared.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: It's in that vein that Willis requested a special purpose grand jury to assist in her investigation.

utterances.speaker: ROBERT JAMES, DISTRICT ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: Special Purpose grand juries are very, very, very rare in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Robert James is one of the few district attorneys who has overseen a special purpose grand jury in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: JAMES
utterances.sentences: Their own powers are much broader than a regular grand juries.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: While a special purpose grand jury doesn't issue indictments, it can be a useful tool for a prosecutor.MICHAEL MOORE, FORMER U.S. ATTORNEY: The DA wanted it because she wanted to use the powers to subpoena people, to get evidence, documentary evidence that she wouldn't otherwise have access to. Special purpose grand jury would get her more information about specific details of the allegation that she was investigating.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: A special purpose grand jury was impaneled in May 2022. And after nearly seven months and 75 witnesses, they authored a report in December 2022 recommending indictments. The sprawling case has involved some of the biggest names in the Trump orbit, as well as some local and state level politicians, many of which you may have never even heard.District Attorney Willis was considering charges under Georgia's Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, referred to as RICO.

utterances.speaker: ELIE HONIG, CNN SENIOR LEGAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: In practical terms, racketeering is a very powerful tool for prosecutors because it enables you to charge a group of people altogether and enables you as a prosecutor to show the jury the full extent of this group.

utterances.speaker: LAURA COATES, CNN CHIEF LEAGAL ANALYST AND ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: it's normally used for the mob, the mafia, organized crime units. Interesting thing about it is you don't actually have to have specific instructions from one person or the next in like a normal conspiracy. It can be as long as you're a part of this whole enterprise, and you've got a common goal, what one is doing in furtherance might impact everyone else.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: And this entire investigation stems back to a single phone call.

utterances.speaker: MARK MEADOWS, FORMER WH CHIEF OF STAFF
utterances.sentences: OK. All right. So, Mr. President, everybody is on the line. And just so this is Mark Meadows, the Chief of Staff, just so we all are aware.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: To this day Trump says he did nothing wrong.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Nobody found anything wrong with that perfect call.

utterances.speaker: FREDROCKA WHITFIELD, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Major breaking news this hour.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Inside a stunning new pressure campaign.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The president was pressuring Georgia Secretary of State to overturn his defeat.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Brad Raffensperger is the Secretary of State in Georgia, and one of the few Republicans who publicly stood up against Trump's conspiracy theories and claims of election fraud after losing the 2020 presidential election.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: OK, thank you very much. Hello, Brad and Ryan, and everybody, we appreciate the time and the call.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Trump was joined by a number of advisers, including Chief of Staff, Mark Meadows, and conservative attorney Cleta Mitchell.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: If we could just go over some of the numbers, I think it's pretty clear that we won. We won very substantially in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: At the time of the election, Gabriel Sterling was the voting systems implementation manager.GABRIEL STERLING (R) CHIEF OPERATING OFFICER, GEORGIA SECRETARY OF STATE'S OFFICE: I was kind of irritated, I wasn't on the call. And then I heard the call the next day. And like, I'm so thankful I was not on that call. It was an hour of which 55 minutes the President spoke. And it was a -- greatest hits of all the stuff that we have been debunking for two months. Give any oxygen to this continued disinformation, is leading to a continuing erosion of people's belief in our elections.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Trump appeared to threaten the Secretary of State.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: You know what they did, and you're not reporting it. That's a- you know, that's a criminal, That's a criminal offense. And you know, you can't let that happen. That's, that's a big risk to you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: This is a really important charge. Solicitation just means you are asking someone to do something. Well, somebody who has sworn an oath of office to serve and protect or uphold the law or represent their constituents, if you were trying to get them and pressure them to do something that would actually be in violation of their oath or even the law, then you may have committed this very crime.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: And then there's this.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I just want to find 11,780 votes, which is one more than we have. Because we won the state.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: 11,780, the exact number of votes Trump needed to win Georgia.How are you taking this?

utterances.speaker: BRAD RAFFENSPERGER, GEORGIA SECRTARY OF STATE
utterances.sentences: Well, I realized there weren't the votes to find. We had checked out all the allegations, so we knew that we had the right results.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Raffensperger refused to budge.

utterances.speaker: RAFFENSPERGER
utterances.sentences: But Mr. President did challenge that you have is the data you have is wrong.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: By this point, robins burger had overseen three separate ballot counts, conducted many other reviews of the process and investigated more than 250 claims of voter fraud. The fact remained, Trump had lost the state of Georgia.

utterances.speaker: RAFFENSPERGER
utterances.sentences: All I knew is we had to, you know, lean into the law and into the facts. And we had both on our side.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: Then President Donald Trump made phone calls to a handful of elected officials in Georgia in the aftermath of the 2020 elections. He called Frances Watson who was then an investigator in the Secretary of State's office.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: The people of Georgia are so angry at what happened to me. They know I won. I won by hundreds of 1000s of votes. It wasn't close. Whatever you could do, Frances, it would be a great thing. It's an important thing for the country.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: The former president called Attorney General Chris Carr in December 2020, asking him basically not to get involved as Texas was fighting Georgia's election results at the Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Trump also made phone calls to officials requesting a special session of the legislature. So Georgia legislators could appoint their own electors, instead of the ones for Biden, the voters had selected. He called the former Speaker of the Georgia House of Representatives.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: David Ralston, a Republican.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: And the governor.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: He made at least two phone calls to Governor Kemp.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Both refused to call for a special legislative session.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: There was a very orchestrated, calculated process going on around us in Georgia trying to get us to change our minds and put pressure on us.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: So far, we haven't been able to find the people with the courage to do the right thing.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: This is Trump, just hours after Governor Brian Kemp declined his request.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Your governor could stop it very easily. If he knew what the hell he was doing, he could stop it very easily.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump was -- was intimately involved in every process around trying to overturn this election. I mean, this was a granular ground game of epic proportions. This was somebody obsessed with overturning that election at all costs.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Up next.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Why are you flying down from DC on December 3 to the Georgia State Capitol for some nothing subcommittee hearing?RUDY GIULIANI, FMR. TRUMP ATTORNEY: Dead people --

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Rudy Giuliani hijacks the Georgia legislature. So he lied?

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: For Jen Jordan, December 3, 2020, began as she expected. The then Georgia Democratic State Senator made her way downtown to the Capitol for a meeting.JEN JORDAN, FORMER STATE SENATOR (D-GA): There was a government oversight meeting to talk about what happened in the elections and the issues. And it ended up being a pretty straightforward committee hearing.

utterances.speaker: RYAN GERMANY, FORMER GENERAL COUNSEL, GEORGIA SECRETARY OF STATE OF OFFICE
utterances.sentences: We have not seen anything that would suggest widespread fraud or widespread problems with --

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: here I am thinking OK, great. We've answered some of these conspiracies, we've dealt with the issues. It felt like an adult committee hearing. So I went to my office and then I almost immediately get a text. Somebody was like, you've got to get over to the Capitol. Something's going on. UNIDENTIFIED MALE

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Unbeknownst to Jordan, her Republican colleague, then State Senator William Ligon, convened another separate special committee to look into questions of election fraud.These complaints deserve full investigation.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: And his committee ended up playing host to Rudy Giuliani and many of these election deniers related to the Trump campaign.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: God bless you.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: God bless you too.(inaudible)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We love you, Rudy.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: Distinguished members of the committee, thank you very much for giving us this hearing. I represent President Trump along with Jenna Ellis.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Rudy Giuliani is in a lot of hot water. This is not someone who might be able to feign they weren't aware of the law. This is somebody who really had been known for RICO prosecutions, as a top prosecutor in New York.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Rudy Giuliani wasn't the only surprise appearance.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The news media were not the usual characters. People like the Epic Times, Newsmax OAN, all of -- all of these various news outlets that had a very particular view. And it was incredibly troubling, what really triggered serious alarm bells is when the tweet went out from the then president.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: President Trump fired off this tweet to his millions of followers ahead of the hearing, directing them to One American News network to watch what would unfold at the Georgia capitol.What does that tell you about who the audience was for this production?

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: As the lieutenant governor at the time, Geoff Duncan served as the president of the Georgia Senate.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: Those weren't official meetings. I didn't sanction those. They wanted a special session because that added one layer of authenticity to their conspiracy theories.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Perhaps the most egregious allegations came in the form of a video. The Trump team presented what they claimed was evidence of fraud from election night ballot tabulating at the State Farm Arena in downtown Atlanta. It purported to show a number of nefarious moments including sending election observers home to secretly count ballots.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Four people to stay behind and continue counting and tabulating well into the night.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: They claimed election workers were pulling out suitcases of hidden ballots after others were sent home.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Once everyone has gone, coast is clear, they are going to pull ballots out from underneath a table.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: And scanning ballots multiple times.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: How many ballots went through those machines in those two hours when there was no one there to supervise? We believe that could easily be and probably is certainly beyond the margin of victory.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The story she told was just chilling, in terms of look at what they're doing. You -- video doesn't lie.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: And when you look at what you saw on the video, which to me was a smoking gun.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The problem was is that the video had been selectively edited.

utterances.speaker: STERLING
utterances.sentences: They found their magical suitcase full of ballots when I'm looking at it like that's a ballot carrier. Those are sealed ballot carriers, which is a normal thing you'd have in elections. They intentionally misled the state Senate in order to keep pushing this narrative and try to get the election thrown out.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: So he lied.

utterances.speaker: STERLING
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, they never backed off from it.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: The FBI and the Department of Justice also got involved in chasing the allegations. Both came to the same conclusion as the Secretary of State's office.BILL BARR, FMR U.S. ATTORNEY GENERAL: My opinion then, and my opinion now is that the election was not stolen by fraud.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: There was no illegal activity by the election workers.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: There has to be a villain or the enemy. And in this hearing in particular, the villain really was the election workers in Fulton County.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: There's more than ample evidence to conclude that this election was a sham.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Once that video was made public and misrepresented as evidence of fraud, two of the women counting ballots, Ruby Freeman and her daughter Shaye Moss were doxxed. Their faces, names addresses, phone numbers, shared online. A (Motley Crue) emerged phoning Freeman and showing up at her home. Stephen Lee, a pastor from suburban Chicago, parked outside Freeman's house until she dialed 911.

utterances.speaker: STEPHEN LEE, PASTOR
utterances.sentences: And I'm a pastor and I'm also working with some folks who are trying to help Ruby out.

utterances.speaker: OFFICER
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: LEE
utterances.sentences: OK. And also get some truth of what's going on. It would be nice if I could talk to her.

utterances.speaker: RUBY FREEMAN, GA ELECTION WORKER
utterances.sentences: I don't trust nobody.

utterances.speaker: OFFICER
utterances.sentences: OK, so you don't want to talk to him? No, Ok.

utterances.speaker: FREEMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm not interested. I have a pastor.

utterances.speaker: OFFICER
utterances.sentences: OK. Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Almost three weeks later, Trevian Kutti, a publicist, who had previously done work for R. Kelly and Kanye West, also showed up in Georgia. Freeman agreed to talk to Kutti at a police precinct. According to court documents, Kutti allegedly pressured Freeman.

utterances.speaker: TREVIAN KUTTI, PUBLICIST
utterances.sentences: We have probably 48 hours in which to move you.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Offering her protection, if she would confess to engaging in election fraud, even though Freeman had done nothing wrong. I cannot say what specifically, will take place. I just know that it will disrupt your freedom. You are a loose end for a party that needs to tidy up.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: One of the most specific and powerful allegations in the indictment is this claim that various defendants tried to intimidate and harass these election workers and tried to get them then to change their story as part of a cover up. That to me is one of the pieces of conduct here that a jury can most readily understand and say, OK, that's a crime.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Freeman and Moss later testified in front of the January 6 committee about vile racist threats they received.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Giuliani has conceded as part of a civil lawsuit that he made defamatory statements about the two election workers. Nearly every other Georgia election official who stood up to the lies received similar threats.

utterances.speaker: CROWD
utterances.sentences: Stop the steal. RAFFENSPERGER

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: It wasn't just you, it was your family members.

utterances.speaker: RAFFENSPERGER
utterances.sentences: Yep, a wife mostly. And she got she got the more vile, you know, personal kind of stuff.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: State Patrol and heightened security and bomb sniffing dogs. And there was a website that formed that put a picture of my house and my address and my name and my kid's name.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: You should go to jail, you are Judas, you're a traitor. You've committed treason.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: The December 3 hearing would bring even more chaos to the state in the aftermath of the election, when then little known attorney appeared.What do you remember about John Eastman's presentation that day?

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: I thought it was ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: JOHN EASTMAN, TRUMP ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: These significant statutory violations are in my view, more than enough.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: He saw it as the duty of the legislature to step in, and basically throw out the will of Georgia voters and for the legislature to convene a special session and appoint their own Republican alternate electors.

utterances.speaker: EASTMAN
utterances.sentences: I don't think it's just your authority to do that. But quite frankly, I think you have a duty to do that to protect the integrity of the election here in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: He didn't have a clue what he was talking about. I'm like he's wrong.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Part of what he is accused of doing is trying to persuade members of the Legislative Branch in Georgia, using false information, using outright lies to try to get them to act against the interests of the people and the voters of Georgia. It's a very serious charge.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: The December 3 Hearing wouldn't be the only appearance by Giuliani and other Trump allies in the Peach State. Giuliani appeared at two other hearings in front of the Georgia legislature in December 2020, where he continued to push the debunked claims of fraud.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: There are 10 ways to demonstrate that this election was stolen, that the votes were phony, that there were a lot of them, dead people, felons, phony ballots.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: And at the last hearing where Giuliani appeared on December 30, the Senate subcommittee that State Senator William Ligon chaired released a report with their findings. The first stating, "The November 3, 2020, election was chaotic, and the results cannot be trusted."

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: That basically regurgitated a lot of those conspiracy theories and -- and half truths about the vote count in Georgia without actually investigating any of those claims. And that report, in turn ended up being cited by the Trump campaign, and many others in their pushes to invalidate election results elsewhere.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: So the report comes out. What kind of weight did that carry?

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: It had none. But again, that really wasn't the point.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: The day after the indictment was released, Giuliani appeared on WABC Radio.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: I woke up this morning, more excited than I have in weeks. We're going to beat these fascists into the ground.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Coming up.So you follow him? A secret meeting at the Capitol?

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: The indictment lays bare the secrecy involved in this scheme.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: This scheme played out here inside the Georgia State Capitol on December 14, 2020, and is the subject of more than a dozen charges listed in the Georgia indictment.

utterances.speaker: GEORGE CHIDI, JOURNALIST
utterances.sentences: I'm driving by the Capitol because I'd heard there might be something going on. And as I turn the corner, I see this big black -- thought was an SUV it was an armored personnel carrier. And Alex Jones out of the cupola at the top looking out like a dime store Mussolini just exhorting people like don't let them take this away from you, off in the distance.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: George GT is a Democrat and a local Georgia journalist who reports on politics and crime in his blog,' The Atlanta Objective.' He covered the far right groups that descended on the Georgia capitol for 'Stop the Steal' rallies after the 2020 election.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: While the tweets themselves standing alone in isolation are not necessarily criminal, the argument the prosecutors will make is this is evidence of the scheme. This is evidence of his intent that he was planning for a long time.

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: I thought maybe the 3 percent militia or some other group were going to show up to do something stupid, and I wanted to bear witness.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: So did you see any of those types when you got to Georgia State Capitol.

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: I didn't?

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: What she did see was a conservative activist who he recognized from his reporting.

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: A, why are you here? He really didn't make eye contact with me. And he went into a room in the Capitol. I'm looking around at who else is seeing this, like, hey, does anybody know what's going on in that room?

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Room 216 at the Georgia State Capitol, just one floor below where the Democratic electors are meeting to certify the Georgia vote for President Elect Biden. So you follow him?

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: I followed him.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Did you go into the room?

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: I went into the room, and I walked in the door. Yes, hey, what's going on here? What? What are you doing? Like what's is this? We're having a meeting, and it was a woman's voice, and I'm looking around and I've got the thing going, and then she says, who's got a camera going? And then another fellow comes and just sort of hustles me out and said, but what -- what is this meeting? And she says it's an education meeting.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: So they told you it was an education meeting.

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: Yes and then they all but frogmarched be out of the room, and then they posted somebody out front to make sure nobody else went in.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: So were you convinced it was an education meeting.

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: I was convinced it was exactly what I thought it was. MURRAY

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: Many of the Republicans who served as alternate electors that mid-December day were high up figures in the state party.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Georgia Republicans who served as fake electors were labeled targets in the Fulton County investigation, though some were later granted immunity.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: With the head of the table was David Shafer, who was the current Chair of the GOP in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Shafer played a key role in organizing Georgia's fake slate of electors by securing the room and convening them at the Capitol. According to the indictment, Shafer sent a text message to another co- conspirator before the meeting. "Listen, tell them to go straight to room 216 to avoid drawing attention to what we're doing," he wrote.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: The fact that they were trying to evade detection, maybe demonstrates to you that they knew what they were doing was wrong. And according to the allegations in the indictment, criminal.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Shafer also served as one of the fake electors.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Afterwards, he said he had acted in response to what the Trump campaign had told him.DAVID SHAFER, STATE SENATOR (R-GA): Because the President's lawsuit contesting the Georgia election has not been decided or even heard, we held this meeting to preserve his rights had we not held the meeting, then his lawsuit would effectively be mooted.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Shafer's attorneys said he broke no laws and was following legal advice when he cast a 'contingent ballot' for Trump.

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: I've never been thrown out of a meeting in a in a public legislative space. Like that's unheard of. But you know, I wasn't being disruptive. They didn't have a good reason to do it. There are no such things as secret meetings at the state capitol. Like that's just not how things work. I think they absolutely were trying to hide something at least at first.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Shafer's attorney told CNN that his client did not try to keep things secret. But that claim is contradicted by an email the fake electors received just 18 hours before they met at the Capitol. The email sent by Robert Sinners, the Trump campaigns election day operations lead in Georgia at the time, asked for, "complete secrecy and discretion."

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: He told them to conceal what they were going to do.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: The email instructed the fake electors to tell security guards they were attending a meeting with two then state senators, Brandon Beach and Burt Jones. According to the author of the letter, he was directed to send it by Trump campaign lawyers and David Shafer.MICHAEL MOORE, FORMER U.S. ATTORNEY: in a process that is probably one of the most public things that the government does to get an email from somebody saying keep all this secret and under the radar, there's probably no good motive behind it. And I think it's good evidence of intent.

utterances.speaker: ROBERT SINNERS, FORMER TRUMP CAMPAIGN STAFFER
utterances.sentences: We were just, you know, kind of kind of useful idiots or rubes at that point. You know, a strong part of me really feels that it's just kind of as the road continued and as that was failure, failure, failure that -- that that got formulated as what do we have on the table? Let's just do it.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: There was evidence of a larger plan orchestrated by a number of operatives in Trump's orbit outside of the state of Georgia. Much of that laid out from another investigation.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: The January 6 Committee on Capitol Hill has really helped Fani Willis and her criminal investigation here. According to a final report from the January 6 committee, the motivation behind creating the slate of fake electors in Georgia and other states was to create enough chaos to persuade then Vice President Mike Pence to subvert the Constitution and throw out the 2020 election results on January 6.The Fulton County prosecutors zeroed in on John Eastman's part in the plot.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: They were very interested in his alleged role at the center of coming up with the scheme of appointing these Republican electors.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: In emails listed in the indictment, the conservative attorney laid out the fake electoral scheme to his co-conspirators. Eastman also made various unfounded claims of voter fraud when he pushed the plan to overturn Biden's victory to Georgia lawmakers.Prosecutors say Eastman knew some of the voter fraud information was not true when he submitted falsified court documents that challenge Georgia's vote.

utterances.speaker: EASTMAN
utterances.sentences: The constitutional power to decide on the method for choosing electors remains exclusively with the state legislatures.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Eastman's attorneys said his involvement was political but not criminal. New York Attorney, Kenneth Chesbro, was also a focus due to his alleged role coordinating the plan and execution of the fake electors. As part of this plan, Chesbro sent an email to Mike Roman, Trump's National Campaign Director, the day before the fake electors scheme. Chesbro wrote that Giuliani wants to keep this quiet until after all the voting is done, according to the indictment. Chesbro's attorneys said he was asked by the Trump campaign to provide advice and was not privy to the private communications of other individuals that are cited in the indictment.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: There was legal structure to this, there was constitutional structure to this, there was logistics, there was secrecy. There's no doubt in my mind that this started in the Oval Office and worked its way outward.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Coming up inside the plot to cease voting data.

utterances.speaker: ZACHARY COHEN, CNN NATIONAL SECURITY REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Really who's who of election deniers.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: All caught on tape.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: About 200 miles southeast of Metro Atlanta sits Coffee County. It's a rural area with a population of about 43,000. In the 2020 election, Donald Trump captured about 70 percent of the vote in this conservative County. It's also the site of a major data breach at the county's election offices involving some of the most vocal conspiracy theorists in the Trump orbit.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: The story of Coffee County was really under the radar. There was an effort to gain access to voting systems specifically in Georgia. Trump wanted to find evidence of fraud, to find evidence that would support those baseless conspiracy theories that he was pushing. And the idea was once you get a copy of the voting system, then you can produce the evidence that there was widespread fraud.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Coffee County, seen as a Trump friendly area became a target for those looking to access voting systems.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: January 7, 2021, was the day that they finally were led in the front doors.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: And it was all caught on tape.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: Technicians from the data services firm, SullivanStrickler were led into the elections office by Cathy Latham, who at the time was the Chairwoman of the Republican Party in Coffee County, and who a couple of weeks earlier had served as one of the 16 fake electors in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Latham initially denied the election equipment had been accessed until security footage proved otherwise. And evidence now shows Latham communicated directly with the then election supervisor in Coffee County, Misty Hampton about getting access to the office.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: You see on the surveillance video. They spend hours inside this restricted room in the elections office.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Ultimately, they were able to basically take an entire copy of the voting system with the idea that it would be used to, you know, point to vulnerabilities point to different issues with the voting machines themselves. And the plan was to use that as evidence of widespread voter fraud.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Another shocking twist in the story, the Coffee County data breach would remain secret for 20 months.When did you guys learn that there was you know, potential breach involving Coffee County?

utterances.speaker: STERLING
utterances.sentences: About a year after it happened, and when we heard about this at first, it actually got sprung on us in a lawsuit.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: That lawsuit which is unrelated to the 2020 election was filed in 2017, after an independent coalition initially sued the Secretary of State over the security of the Georgia voting system. The video of the data breach was one piece of evidence in that civil suit. But it revealed exactly what these Trump supporters were up to after he lost the state.

utterances.speaker: STERLING
utterances.sentences: They played a little snippet of an audio of one of the plaintiffs talking to a person claiming to have done this.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: That person was Scott Hall. The man scene here in the surveillance footage. Hall is an Atlanta area bail bondsman, who served as a pole watcher and according to the indictment, has been looking into the election on behalf of the President.

utterances.speaker: SCOTT HALL, ATLANTA AREA BAIL BONDSMAN
utterances.sentences: I'm the guy that chartered the jet to go down to Coffee County to have them inspect all of those computers. They scanned all the equipment, imaged all the hard drives and scanned every single ballot.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Without that recording of Scott Hall, we'd probably never know what we know now.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Can you imagine the idea of having tangible from the proverbial horse's mouth information to present to a grand jury is invaluable. This goes a long way in the form of giving direct evidence as to what was planned, who was involved and what was intended.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: And it gave Fani Willis and the Fulton County DAs office the evidence it needed to charge Hall and Misty Hampton, Coffee County's election supervisor with conspiracy and violating Georgia's RICO Act.Did you have any sense this was tied to maybe other operatives in the Trump campaign that it was anything beyond sort of lower level people in Coffee County?

utterances.speaker: RAFFENSPERGER
utterances.sentences: Not initially but their allegations and as you dig down deep more is revealed.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Further revelations came when the Fulton County DA 's office charged Kathy Latham with 11 crimes, ranging from impersonating a public officer to conspiracy. But more importantly, it connected the dots between Coffee County and the White House.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: Sidney Powell was the one who ended up commissioning the services of SullivanStrickler.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Her involvement is really what exposes the broader Trump team's involvement in Coffee County.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Powell advocated seizing voting machines with an executive order from Trump at an explosive White House meeting in December 2020.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Another idea that was pitched during that meeting was raised by Rudy Giuliani and he thought that they could coerce or convince local election officials to voluntarily give their investigators access to voting systems.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: In other words, exactly what happened in Coffee County on January 7, 2021.

utterances.speaker: STERLING
utterances.sentences: I think when you start with the President of United States saying the election was stolen, nothing is surprising to me.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Despite searching for evidence that would back up their theories of election fraud, there is no indication there were any voting irregularities discovered during the data breach. And to this day, we don't know where the data lives and how exactly the Trump supporters plan to use it.Up next.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: We're about to have the David and Goliath fight.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: The extraordinary challenges of trying to indict a former president.

utterances.speaker: STERLING
utterances.sentences: If they indict Him and they can't convict them it will be an exoneration.(COMMERCIAL BREAK) [20:50:00] MURRAY: After nine weeks of countless misleading comments, half-truths and flat out lies, a violent deadly insurrection exploded at the nation's Capitol.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's over.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: In the midst of the riot, then Lieutenant Governor of Georgia Geoff Duncan begged residents of his state involved to stand down.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: I want to speak directly to Georgians, every Georgian that can hear my voice, put down your differences. Put down your partisanship.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: More than 20 Georgia residents would go on to face charges, stemming from their actions in Washington DC on January 6, according to its CNN tally.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump stopped caring about this country the moment he started lying about that election. The conspiracy theories that literally seeded the beginnings and endings of January 6, in my personal opinion is a direct attack against democracy itself.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: The election lies and conspiracy theories may have reached their apex on January 6. But even now, more than two years later, Donald Trump refuses to acknowledge the 2020 election results.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: It was a rigged election. I ran twice, I won twice.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: And still can't accept his loss in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We have elections that were horrible. If you look at what happened in Atlanta, millions of votes and all you have to do is take a look at government cameras.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Every individual charged in the indictment is charged with participation in a criminal enterprise in Fulton County, Georgia.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: The Georgia indictment, Trump's fourth only intensifies the already unprecedented moment in American history.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I consider it a badge, a great, great, beautiful badge of honor and courage, because I'm being indicted for you.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: District Attorney Fani Willis has said she wants to try all 19 defendants at the same time.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: We will be asking for a trial date within the next six months.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: It will be a story of legends to try it 19 defendants in a case of this magnitude within six months. JAMES

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: And Trump isn't just a former president. He's also the leading Republican candidate for 2024.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: You have to find 12 people who aren't so passionate about Donald Trump, that they're able to judge the case fairly and impartially based only on the facts and law in the courtroom. So the fact that he's running for president really complicates everything here.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: But his candidacy is a point he could try to use to his advantage in the courtroom.You're Donald Trump in this, how do you juggle the court dates? Again, 2-3-4 indictments with campaigning for president of the United States?

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think that's going to be a legitimate issue he brings up to the court. And while we all want to see some resolution, I don't think there's any question that he's got a good, credible case to make, that he shouldn't be forced now, to have to try his case in the middle of a presidential primary.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: What happens if he's reelected President of the United States before these cases are decided?

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: The question is the same as we got to at the end of his last term, and that is, does he have the authority to pardon himself?

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: We are again in uncharted territory of whether he'd be able to use that on himself if Trump in fact, were re-elected to the presidency, but at the state level, that is kind of untouchable for the President of United States. You see, federalism ensures that the states have certain rights. And one of them, of course, would mean that the pardoning power of a president would not apply to the States or their convictions.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: We're nearly three years past the pressure campaigns, the harassment of public and private citizens, the coordinating of fake electors, the breach of election systems, and we still don't know, will Trump be convicted in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: They rigged the presidential election in 2020. And we're not going to allow them to rig the presidential election of 2024.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Do you see any risk in moving forward with indictment of former President? I mean, are we setting any kind of a dangerous precedent?

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: I think we're setting a dangerous precedent if we don't move forward, if we don't hold him accountable. I think the risk is much more significant.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: You saw former President Trump lie to the American people, you saw him gin up this outrage. Is it a remedy if he's charged with a crime in Georgia?

utterances.speaker: STERLING
utterances.sentences: If they indict him, and they can't convict them, it will be an exoneration. Is that better? Or is that worse? I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: What I could envision is that we actually live in a society where Lady Justice is blind. And that it doesn't matter if you're rich, poor, black, white, Democrat or Republican. If you violated the law, you're going to be charged.(END VIDEO CLIP)
